title: Before 15 November 2017, will the WTO establish a dispute settlement panel for any of Qatar's complaints against Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, or Bahrain?
preds: Update: 3 days ago Qatar asked for a dispute panel due to UAE blockade. UAE says blockade is due to National Security thus making WTO inoperable. In any case, the earliest a panel could be called to start an investigation as to whether to have a panel is Nov 22 or after close for this question.
dispute in region is ongoing and western powers are very interested in stability.
I don't think this can happen in time, but it will happen soon.

This has been one of our most difficult years: Qatar Airlines CEO	This has been one of our most difficult years: Qatar Airlines CEO  
8 Hours Ago | 03:24
The CEO of Qatar Airways has called on President Donald Trump to do more to end an economic blockade of his country. Qatar is locked in a dispute with neighboring countries which has curtailed airspace rights over the nation. The airline's management predicts it will swing to a full-year loss as a result of the diplomatic standoff. Speaking at the CAPA aviation conference in Singapore, Akbar Al Baker told CNBC Tuesday that the U.S. leader must act faster. "President Trump is trying to do more, but I think he needs to do even more because he has given an undertaking to my ruler that he will solve the problem and he will solve it soon," he said. "And we are depending on him," Al Baker added. The airlines boss said the U.S. had a responsibility to protect Qatar. "We are an American ally, you have a very large American community in my country. You have important assets and interests in my country. As Americans, you should never allow such a thing to happen to my country," he said
https://www.cnbc.com/2017/11/07/qatar-airways-ceo-calls-on-trump-to-do-even-more-on-gulf-blockade.html
——————————
COMMENTS:  if that CEO counts on President Trump, than he will have to wait a bit longer than Nov. 15
Very unlikely. With only a few days left to meet this deadline (& with escalating political tensions in the region) a settlement is unlikely.

I found it really interesting that the consensus is so low on this one.   Here are the facts that I think people are missing: 
1) Consultation Period (60 Days from complaint)
2) Establishment of a Panel (45 Days from request) Does this play out in practice?   Dispute Country & Number: Request for Panel & Panel Establish Date (Days from Request)
Ukraine DS512: 40
Turkey DS513: 39
China DS516: 25
USA DS517: 35
Japan DS518: 25
Brazil DS522: 42
USA DS523: 39 Average days to establish a panel: 35
So yes, they do a good job following the state goal of 45 days or less, with an average of just 35 days Note: Each of these also had a panel deferral announced in the middle.  
Average days since deferral: 23 What does this mean?  
Qatar DS526:  Request for Panel - 10/6/2017
Qatar DS526: Panel Deferral - 10/25/2017 Qatar DS526: Establishment Date?    Well, we know that it can't be any later than 10/6/2017+45 days.  
So no later than November, 20th We also know that "on average" they will establish it on:
- November 10th (based on days since request)
- November 16th (based on days since deferral) This puts a very very high probability on them getting it established before November 15th.
The one countervailing point here is that the next official Dispute Settlement Body meeting isn't until November 22nd.  However, this puts it past the 45 day deadline, by a few days.  Is this enough to warrant a special session?  
https://www.wto.org/english/news_e/events_e/events_e.htm Also note that only dispute #526 against UAE has had a formal request for a panel. With that said, I have applied the averages to establish my probability of roughly 85%.
Oct 21 Qatar asked for panel. Oct 23rd UAE blocked. I do not think it will happen in this time frame.

The base rate of time to set up a Panel means this almost certainly won't happen. See EUI paper http://cadmus.eui.eu/bitstream/handle/1814/47045/LAW_2017_11.pdf?sequence=1 on discrepancy between WTO timeframe and actual disputes processed up to 2011.
There are no meetings scheduled for the remaining time frame. It is (maybe) possible for there to be some informal session put on the calendar similar to October, but I think that is unlikely.
Not after the 60 Minutes section on Sunday night October 29th
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Reference WTO January 2008, only about 136 of the nearly 369 cases had reached the full panel process. Most of the rest have either been notified as settled “out of court” or remain in a prolonged consultation phase — some since 1995.

None of these countries will submit their disputes to a panel.  Trade will continue inspite of the disputes, as Qatar cannot be effectively blockaded nor economically pressured by these countries.  This is a contest of wills and none are stronger that Qatar's.

oops. looks like i messed up this question. whereas previously i'd figured qatar would want this handled quickly (qatar seemed to have moved quickly up to today's meeting), i now see no indication qatar plans to use footnote 5 to article 6.1 (beyond the fact that it gave notice of the first meeting more than 10 days in advance... & i'm not sure whether such notice was required for that meeting or whether the notice provision applies to the second rather than the first meeting, or whether it applies to both).  moreover, there is now a new issue, perhaps more important than timing, raising a question of whether qatar will want to proceed further on wto dispute resolution at all: the u.s. has indicated its displeasure at allowing wto dispute resolution to proceed between qatar and uae b/c uae has raised national security concerns and the u.s. doesn't want the wto in the business of dealing with countries' asserted national security concerns. although i don't see anything on paper that would technically prevent qatar from ignoring the u.s.'s objection to proceed with expedited setup of a wto dispute resolution panel, qatar's incentives may be to defer to the u.s. on this point (assuming qatar has u.s.-related interests that it deems sufficiently more important than the wto dispute(s) such that the interests are not worth risk of u.s. ire caused by insisting on this wto adjudication... much less rapid wto adjudication). that said, there's still time for qatar to require the WTO to form a dispute resolution panel under footnote 5 within the timeframe of the GJO question, if qatar wants it to. (See links in GJO's background/summary of question + https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/593089 .)
UAE has blocked the first request to establish a panel. https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2017/10/23/uae-blocks-qatar-request-wto-ruling/
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

Process required to establish panel goes beyond Nov. 15, details in new WTO statement.
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-wto/qatar-escalates-uae-trade-dispute-asks-wto-to-adjudicate-idUSKBN1CH2VT
Based on general news and GJP consensus.
lowering forecast. but I DSB in the DSB: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VcjzHMhBtf0

There are only 34 days from the time Qatar requested the panel (10/12/2017) and the deadline for this forecast. Looking at over 50 previous disputes in which a panel was requested and established at some point, only about 25% had a panel established within 34 days.  That said, some of those were cases in which the panel was established at the first Dispute Resolution Board meeting following the request. I think that is very unlikely in this case given the general tendency to defer establishment in the first meeting, as well as UAE's non-compliance with the process to this point.  Given that, if we look only at the cases in which a panel was not established in the first DSB meeting, the amount of those having a panel established in the necessary time frame drops to about 20%.  In this case, that would necessitate the DSB scheduling some meeting earlier than the normal meeting scheduled for November 22nd. That seems to be entirely possible, but as we pass the first meeting I will likely downgrade for each day that passes without an interim meeting being scheduled.

Qatar escalates UAE trade dispute, asks WTO to adjudicate
https://www.reuters.com/article/us-gulf-qatar-wto/qatar-escalates-uae-trade-dispute-asks-wto-to-adjudicate-idUSKBN1CH2VT It looks as though Qatar may request that a panel be established regarding the UAE dispute at the October 24th Dispute Settlement Body meeting. The UAE is allowed to block the first request and it appears to be fairly common for countries to do so.  If the UAE does block the request, the next request would have to be made in the following DSB meeting, which isn't scheduled until November 22nd, outside of the question's time frame.  I will be digging around a bit more to attempt to determine the likelihood that UAE will block the request.

edit: https://docs.wto.org/dol2fe/Pages/SS/directdoc.aspx?filename=q:/WT/DS/526-2.pdf qatar/reuters: i thought the dispute settlement body met oct. 23 not oct. 24. https://www.wto.org/english/news_e/events_e/events_e.htm oh well.
The base rate of about 13 in 37 suggests at least one of the cases will proceed to settlement panel.
Why will Saudi Arabia bend to the WTO and what can the WTO do to Saudi Arabia?
According to several commentators, the time left to establish the panel is short considering the WTO procedures.
Expect WTO to go very slow on entering this conflict.
Decreasing probability on the basis of data and analysis by @joew92 at https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/571629. Thank you, Joe Wood. I wish I'd seen your post earlier.
Thank you, @joew92, for your base rate calculations. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/569000

No. The situation will not move from its current state for a long. And definitely not at WTO level. Something in the field or sport is more probable in my opinion. Sport makes more noise than trade if you want to give a political signal to the international community and reach the public. Unless one of the regional big actor fall short of sympathy from its protector, then we will not see changes.
The parties positions appear intractable at the moment.  With positions hardening & the inability of the US to mediate, there is an increasing likelihood that Qatar will resort to arbitration.
The economic power of KSA, UAE  and the strong USA relationship Bahrain has will not give Qatar and equal chance during the negotiations. Therefore they will not accept it.
Based on general news and GJP consensus.

New reports that Qatar is seeking private WTO talks would seem to suggest that the likelihood of a panel at all has diminished, and the likelihood of one being established in the specified timeframe is far less.
No change from previous forecast. Also, I will note that I have always done better by betting on delay than expediency.

The panel is no guarantee of any settlement. There are historical and cultural issues that confuse and complicate. When one looks back and realizes that Bill Clinton wanted to name Carlos Salinas de Gortari to be the first head of the WTO, it was an aberration of soft power and in this case it has escalated into what some might call, uh... "a-symmetical war."

The # of complaints that move to trial is 136/369 according to WTO website (https://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/whatis_e/tif_e/disp1_e.htm) meaning an individual rate of about 37% 
Since there are 3 complaints, the probability of at least one of them going through is around 75% 
That said, from a quick survey of disputes that have gone to panel, only about 20% have done so in the time frame we have available, giving a probability of about 15%. 
It is certainly possible given the time frame for this to make it to panel, but I suspect the respondents will be trying to drag out the process since the continued embargo may soften Qatar. 
Qatar also seems unlikely to drop out of the process in the near term, as crux of the respondents' argument is a claim to a national security exemption from trade laws, which is a sort of fringe exemption and a clarifying ruling could be beneficial to Qatar.
Panel set up and panellists appointed typically within 45 days

Per my comment to @Intriligator: Qatar filed WTO complaint against UAE, Bahrain, SA on July 31:
See: https://www.wto.org/english/news_e/news17_e/ds526_7_8rfc_04aug17_e.htm Looking at docs, they filed under DSU Article 4 (https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/dsu_e.htm#4) Here's the timeline for Article 4: 1. File complaint, wait up to 10 days for a response.
2. Responding parties to enter into negotiations within 30 days.
3. Negotiations given 60 days to reach a resolution. 
4. If no resolution, a panel may be established. So Article 4 plays out in no less than 30 days (no response from anyone) or up to 90 days (if there is a response but everyone drags their feet). And that is assuming that there is no mechanism for extending initial negotiations, which I'm sure there is (but I admittedly couldn't find). Then we move on to establishing a panel. The first question is who will be on the panel. Per the WTO:  "Panels are like tribunals. But unlike in a normal tribunal, the panellists are usually chosen in consultation with the countries in dispute. Only if the two sides cannot agree does the WTO director-general appoint them. Panels consist of three (possibly five) experts from different countries who examine the evidence and decide who is right and who is wrong." From here: https://www.wto.org/english/thewto_e/whatis_e/tif_e/disp1_e.htm My predictions:  1. Initial negotiations will take at least 60 days and will not be successful.
2. The parties will not agree on panel membership, and sorting that out will take at least another 60 days. I agree that a panel is entirely possible, maybe even likely, but I don't think we'll see it before Nov. 15.
With the major countries, no, but with Bahrain or the UAE, perhaps.  The wording in the question is "any" and not "all."
Minimal chance, in case some new and unusual event happens there between now and 11/15. Otherwise, it is local political dispute with many-powerful-vs-one-small and hence WTO is likely to stay away.
I think the timeline is a bit too fast for the WTO.
I doubt that the WTO wants to get itself in the middle of what is really a political dispute.

Qatar, on July 3 2017, filled for consultation with the WTO.  Consultations have begun and the parties to the dispute are required to settle the matter before the 104 day period has started.   There is no clear indication when this mit occur.  If the consultation does not reach agreement under WTO rules, a dispute settlement panel will be convened to adjudicate the dispute.  The.following articles under GATT 1994 has been filed by Qatar: GATT Articles: 1.1, V:2, X1:1, XIII: 1, XXIII:2.  For services using GATS Articles: II:2, III:2, III:3, XXIII:1, XXII3.  For intellectual property rights (TRIPS): 3, 4. There is a moderate to strong likelihood that consultations will not succeed among the parties and that the complaint by Qatar will move into the dispute settlement panel phase.
Consultation phases can drag on for years. While I don't think these disputes will take that long, I also don't believe the WTO moves this fast.

On July 31 Qatar filed a legal complaint at the WTO to challenge the Saudi-Bahrain-UAE trade boycott.  This was the first step in the WTO's trade dispute process, triggering a 60-day deadline for settlement or face potential WTO mediation and litigation, including potential retaliatory trade sanctions, a process which can take years to reach conclusion. The first deadline is September 30.  Given several ongoing diplomatic efforts to lower tensions and find the right mix of concessions that would allow both sides to claim victory, and all parties' reluctance to see this dispute disrupt global energy markets, I would forecast a very low probability that the WTO establishes a dispute settlement panel by November 15, preferring to allow diplomacy and consultations as much time as needed to work.

According to the WTO panel chart, there is a 60 day consultation period before a dispute settlement panel would be formed.  The sanctions imposed, especially by Saudi Arabia, have put a stranglehold on imports needed for full functioning of the country.  The Gulf Cooperation Council is putting a stranglehold on Qatar for supporting the wrong terrorist organizations.  Qatar's counter-move to involve the World Trade Organization is one of their last traditional options and shows the sanctions are having the desired effect.  Qatar has a choice between kneeling to western interests and the GCC or become an isolated peninsula with one land border, with Saudi Arabia, which would become a non-ally if Qatar decides to go the independent direction.  Pride would be the fall of the nation.  I still believe the Gulf Cooperation Council countries will work it out before a formal dispute settlement.

The actual tmeline to resolution may be more flexible than the base 105 days set out in the WTO process.  There is room for flexibility. And there is the possibility of additional parties becoming involved.
Since this seems to be more of a political issue, creation of individual WTO panels to address specific issues may not be the optimal path to a solution.
This is pretty short notice.  Most of the time the WTO can't establish where its head is, using both hands and a Geiger counter.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dispute_settlement_in_the_World_Trade_Organization
So according to wikipedia, the base rate is 105 days and we have 107 days between the 31.07 and 15.11.
I am starting with a low probability as, the dispute might be settle before the panel is set up.
